text: This video was made possible by Skillshare.

Get access to over 20 thousand premium courses
for free for 2 months using the link down
below.
I am so excited. I wonder when my new hardware is going to get here?
What is this... Garbage?

It has been a weird couple of months for someone
more interested in how technology changes
the affordable side of things.

With Nvidia's new generation almost monopolising
the conversation with some gadgets that while

do introduce some pretty amazing technology
follow

an absolutely worrying trend of mainstream
consumer technology dramatically increasing
in costs.

I felt a glimmer of hope when AMD silently
announced a new APU on the Athlon brand.
For years now

the Athlon name has been associated with affordable
CPUs for office or casual application, kinda

like Intel's Pentium, but it has been surprisingly
absent during the current generation until
now,

but this time there is a little something
that makes this APU special.

In what feels like an eternity ago but was
actually just March me and the rest of the

pc gaming internet was fascinated with the
newest low-end member of the ryzen family,
the 2200G.

This fascination stemmed from the fact that
it was the first APU that used their modern

Vega architecture on the integrated GPU giving
it performance way over any IntelHD that I
have seen and closer to dedicated GPUs.
Not bad for a 100 dollar chip.

You can even overclock it and do some VR on
it.
AMD does know their APUs after all.
Now they seem to have noted those lessons that they have learned and taken the concept further to release

the Athlon 200CE which costs a little over
half of the cheapest Ryzen APU.

For that price, we get a 2 core, 4 thread
CPU with an integrated GPU using the same

Vega architecture that gave the 2200G its
magic.
Weaker, but still pretty good.

On the other side, the cost reductions mean
that it does not support overclocking and
that the fastest RAM it supports is 2666 MHz.

The marketing material seems to place it closer
to general use and light productivity and

hey, it can run light video or picture editing
so if you want to spend as little as possible

to start your creative career this is not
a bad option as is getting those creative
skills from

Skillshare, with over 20,000 classes on video
game creation, design, editing…
No, no, NO!
Stop.
We are barely 3 minutes into the video.
Save it for later.

And if you try to look into gaming on this
APU you will notice that the same marketing

material mentions it as viable for e-sports
games, a growing marketing term for things
like League of Legends or CSGO...

Mmm... here is it playing Doom at 720p, 80%
internal resolution scaler and shadows removed

with the console commands from my video on
the topic.

This is not a huge surprise given that vega
supports Vulkan and the insane levels of optimization

of this game that allows it to run in some
really absurd scenarios but it is still pretty
amazing.
Not a bad start for this little guy.

Perhaps more interesting is Wolfstein 2: The
New Colossus.

This is another important case study since
it has given trouble to many of my best-dedicated

GPUs but it has proven effective on Ryzen
APUs and our little Ahtlon was definitely
not excluded.
In order to push the integrated GPU no the maximum, unlike doom,  I decided to push for 720p with no internal

resolution scaler but I used my trick from
the video to disable shadows and just to make

things a bit harder I threw it right in the
middle of a pretty intense combat scene.

The result was almost stable 30 fps, with
the game only dropping to around 25 on the
crazier moments.

This is a crazy good performance for this
game on a device on this price range with
an integrated GPU.
Then is Nier: Automata, running on 960x540.

This game does not get any level of acceptable
performance on its usual low settings, but
if you throw the FAR mod that I talked about on my video on this game and disable global illumination

it can at least keep it close to 30 and just
enough to actually get by with the game.
Honestly, I did not expect this game to work.

Let's keep climbing this hill to try Far Cry
5 on the lowest settings, and a resolution
of 720p and the internal resolution scaler set to 50%

If you watched my video on this topic you
likely know that there is a fair amount of

graphical reduction you can do on this game
on the configuration file and I have added

most of them, except the changes to the draw
distance since I wanted to simulate a state

in which you can actually play the game, and
to my surprise the Athlon averages 53 FPS,
holy cow.

I reckon you could play without all the tweaks
at 30 fps if needed.

How does the performance disaster that is
PUBG on PC work?
Amazingly, that is how.

Here I am playing at 720 and an internal resolution
of 50% via the configuration file and being

indoors out outdoors it can do something close
to 45 fps.
This is another success that I did not expect.
I played a full match without any issue.

A newer addition to my test elements is the
newly released Shadow of the Tomb Raider.

While I am yet to find any way to boost this
game I am working on a video regarding its

DX12 implementation which dramatically reduces
CPU usage and sure enough running the benchmark

on lowest settings, 720p and 50% internal
resolution and DX12 easily lands it an average of over

30 fps, most of the time limited by the integrated
GPU.

Considering this is a game that released not
that long ago this might be as bad as it gets
for GPU performance.

Lighter titles which are closer to whatever
the heck "esports games" meant
obviously do superbly.

Fortnite and its crazy optimization at 1080
but internal resolution set at 50% and lowest

settings provides almost a smooth 60 fps with
drops close to 55 when there is a lot to render

but overall solid performance even in moments
of great necessity.

F2P Quake Champions on minimum settings, 720p
and a 50% internal resolution scaler easily

breaks the 60 fps barrier, only dropping under
that when things get a bit too close and personal

And older but popular games like Rocket League
on 1080 and the lowest presets provides an

expected but solid over 60 fps performance
which borders closer to 80.

And since I know you are going to ask the
CSGO benchmark did spectacularly in 1080,

with over 60 fps in average performance...
and as usual keep in mind that the benchmark's

average is likely lower than what you actually
will see in the game.

Now, something that you might have caught
on here is that for all of this titles the

main bottleneck or limiter of the performance
is the integrated GPU.

Given that part of the appeal of building
a setup with this little guy is its easy upgradability

I was wondering how much of a problem its
dual-core nature can be on CPU heavy titles.

Which finally takes me to the only "esports"
title that I am actually competent: Overwatch.

Overwatch is notorious among the games I like
to test for being exceptionally light on the

GPU but a tad higher in its CPU than most
games out there when aiming for 60 fps.
And that got initially reflected on my test.

As I started playing on the lowest settings,
720p and 50% resolution scaler and look at
those 4 threads suffering.

The iGPU is more than able to aim for 60 fps
initially, but the dual-core CPU can struggle
a fair bit when trying to reach 60 fps.

Thankfully this is easily solvable with a
45 fps cap or more realistically using the

trick I mentioned on one of the Overwatch
videos to auto close battle.net and also remove
everything from the startup

that could be using the CPU and the effect
is very noticeable.
I was able to play a full match comfortably on a 75% resolution scaler. No issues, it just works

Since I wanted to explore the limits of the
CPU I tried Battlefront 2.

While I know what some of the comments will
say, from a technical perspective

the Frostbite engine this run on is probably
the heaviest CPU user of all Engines I have

tried while being considerate in GPU use and
Battlefront 2 is the heaviest game with that
engine until Battlefield V releases.
My testing went as I expected.

On the lowest settings, 720p, 50% resolution
scale and some adjustments from my video using

the terminal the iGPU had plenty of space
to try and reach 60 fps but those 2 cores,
4 threads are struggling quite a bit.

Here it does kinda turn into an issue as frostbite
does tend to micro-stutter when CPU bound
but it is very, very close to getting there.

Limiting it to something like 45 fps gets
rid of the problem entirely and provides a
pretty good gaming experience.

This the one time that I am frustrated that
this CPU is not unlocked and therefore not
overclockable.

I get SO close to being able to pull 60 fps
on a frostbite game that I have a suspicion

that all it would have required as a bit of
an overclock.

Silver-lining is that if you are building
a PC from scratch you can cheap out on the
motherboard and get an A320 chipset.

Which is a great transition into the next
section:
How budget oriented is it?

For purposes of this video, I decided to act
like I was building a PC in 3 different locations:
The US, Spain and India.

I picked this APU as the CPU and GPU, a cheap
motherboard for this socket that does not

support overclocking and the cheapest dual channel ram
at the highest supported speed, 2666 MHz.

As you probably noticed the price of DDR4
ram continues to be the Achilles hill of modern
APU builds and this time they are by far the most expensive component.

On the Ryzen 2200g video, I complained that
in order to keep the build under my target

prices sacrifices had to be made in RAM speed
which ultimately doomed the speed of the APU.

RAM speed is very important for iGPU performance
after all, although I am working on a better
video measuring this.
Subscribe so you know when that comes out.

Since this APU is half the price that means
that we can easily get the best-supported

RAM while still maintained a price under 200
euros, or near 220 for India, for the core
motherboard, ram, CPU and GPU.

Thanks to that I was able to get any game
I wanted somehow running on this thing with
no major exceptions.

If you want to get into PC gaming and you
absolutely need to spend as little as possible

I would still recommend something like paying
super low prices from a trash 775 PC with a

quad-core CPU, 8 gb of DDR2 ram, a cheap used
GPU or a gt 1030 if you can find it at a good
price.

But as people like to point out in those videos
you are basically sacrificing future upgradability

for lower cost, which is a valid decision
if you are desperate.

However, if you want to spend as little as
possible, only buy new components and want

to leave plenty of room for upgradability
I genuinely think this is the best choice.

With a small core spending, you get a PC that
you can get a ton of games working on low
or ultra-low settings but still pretty playable, some of them

with very surprising performance that rivals
a lot of cheap dedicated GPUs that would cost almost

as much as the whole APU and if you want to
upgrade to the next level down the road,

it is just a matter of adding a better dedicated
GPU to do that work and the Athlon cpu is

perfectly able to keep up on most games in
low settings.

For example, for a quick experiment, I added
a Radeon RX550

that I used for a video on playing in 4k and
that is sandwiched somewhere between a GT
1030 and a GTX 1050 in terms of performance, at least in my experience.

On doom on full 720 and shadows enabled, it
went way over 60 fps before hitting a CPU
bottleneck.

Far Cry 5 in full 720 and no graphical tweaks
was averaging 55 and only hitting CPU limits
in very specific places.

Shadow of the Tomb Raider is the newest game
on the list,  with a dedicated GPU and directX

12 was able to reach near 45 fps on the most
CPU heavy areas of the benchmark with no stuttering.

You can get away with playing 45 to 60 fps
in a lot of games before feeling that you
want to upgrade your CPU.

And when the time comes and you do want to
upgrade the CPU as well it uses the same socket

as all current Ryzens so you have a ton of
modern quadcore CPUs to go to.

So in conclusion, when everyone was flocking
at the Ryzen 2200g as the saviour of budget

builds of this generation I liked the device
but was not fully convinced.
While the 200ge is not perfect, it could use an Overclock, it is much closer to what I
expected back then.

It's half the price and when paired with the
right RAM

it can run pretty much anything I threw at
it using the knowledge accumulated over many
of my videos, which means you can get a ton out of it as your only CPU and GPU for a long time while
leaving plenty of space open for future upgrades.

Considering that it a bit over half the price
of the cheapest Ryzen APU I think it is a

fantastic value, as is investing in yourself
and your skills

with Skillshare which you can start doing
for free with access all the premium tutorials
for 2 months with the link down below.

If you have considering making a video game
to explore a new dimension of your creativity,

like many of us have, a prefer working with
examples you can use this class

I found on building a basic Unity kart game
in just one hour.

You have to start somewhere and Skillshare
is a great somewhere.

Thank you to them for sponsoring this video,
and you for supporting in Patreon.
